strings.birth_desc: {name} the Stabyhoun was born on this day.
strings.walk_rule: Rule: {mins} minutes per walk, twice a day.
strings.age_desc: {name} the Stabyhoun is now {weeks} weeks old.
strings.error_dob_future: Date of birth cannot be in the future
strings.error_months_max: Choose a plan length between 1 and 12 months.
strings.error_plan_start: Enter a valid plan start date
strings.error_meals: Enter at least 1 meal per day
strings.title: Puppy planner
strings.share_message: Plan your puppy walkies and food schedule
strings.share_platform_prompt: Choose where to share this plan:
strings.mixed_mode_hint: Mixed mode is optional. Pick one wet and one dry food.
strings.mixed_validation_choose_second: Select a second food to apply mixed mode.
strings.mixed_validation_duplicate: Choose two different products for mixed mode.
strings.mixed_validation_wet_dry_required: Mixed mode requires one wet and one dry food.
strings.mixed_validation_min_total: Mixed mode requires at least {min} g/day total. Use single-food mode below that.
strings.result_empty_hint: Select a food and enter your dog's details below
strings.mixed_rounding_note: Amounts are rounded up per food. Combined total can be +1 to +2 g above the base recommendation.
strings.url_values_adjusted: Some link values were adjusted to safe defaults.
strings.hint_dob: Choose the date of birth so planning starts correctly.
strings.hint_birthday: Adds automatic birthday reminders to the schedule.
strings.hint_months: Choose 1 to 12 months. Initial value is 3.
strings.hint_start: Walk planning starts from this date.
strings.hint_age_months: For puppy food, enter age in months.
strings.hint_age_years: For non-puppy food, enter age in years.
strings.footer_about_1: This tool helps you create a practical walking and feeding plan for your dog.
strings.footer_about_2: You can share settings through the URL so others see the same plan immediately.
strings.footer_brand_text: Next to your dog, Casey does IT
strings.footer_disclaimer: Disclaimer: this is a planning aid and not veterinary advice.
strings.footer_food_data_cta: Add your food data to PuppyCal
strings.dog_hint_empty: Add your dog's profile for personalised results
strings.mixed_no_opposite: Add a food of the opposite type to enable mixed mode.
strings.assumption_model: Reference model reverse-engineered from public calculator behavior; exact vendor internals are unknown.
strings.assumption_kcal_fallback: Uses kcal density {density} kcal/kg (fallback reference when product calories are missing).
strings.assumption_advisory: Advisory planning aid only; not veterinary advice.

generic: Development: At 8 weeks, puppies are in a 'fear imprint' stage. Positive experiences are crucial right now.
Health: A puppy's growth plates are soft and don't close until 12-18 months. This is why we limit walking time.
Activity: Mental stimulation (sniffing, puzzles) tires a puppy out 3x faster than physical walking.
Development: At 12 weeks, your puppy's permanent teeth will start pushing out the milk teeth.
Sleep: Puppies this age need 18-20 hours of sleep a day to grow properly.
Socialization: The 'Rule of 12' suggests meeting 12 new people, surfaces, and sounds by 12 weeks.
Training: Recall training starts now! Use their name and high-value treats.
Health: Avoid stairs and jumping in and out of cars to protect their joints.
Fact: Dogs have sweat glands only in their paw pads.
Fact: A dog's nose print is as unique as a human fingerprint.
Development: By 16 weeks, the critical socialization window begins to close.
Activity: A 10-minute sniff walk is better than a 20-minute power walk for a puppy.
Diet: Puppies grow fast! Monitor their weight weekly to adjust food portions.
Bonding: Hand-feeding your puppy can help prevent resource guarding.
stabyhoun: Stabyhoun Fact: The name 'Stabyhoun' roughly translates from Frisian to 'Stand by me dog'.
Stabyhoun Fact: They are one of the top 5 rarest dog breeds in the world.
Breed Fact: Stabyhouns originate from the province of Friesland in the Netherlands.
Breed Fact: Historically, they were the 'poor man's dog', capable of hunting, guarding, and catching moles.
Breed Fact: Stabyhouns are known for having a 'soft mouth', meaning they can retrieve game without damaging it.
Breed Fact: Unlike many hunting breeds, the Stabyhoun is known to be an independent thinker and can be stubborn.
Fun Fact: Stabyhouns love water! They were often used to retrieve ducks.
Grooming: The Stabyhoun is 'self-cleaning'. Dirt usually falls off their coat once it dries.
Breed Fact: The tips of a Stabyhoun's ears often have shorter hair at the bottom, unlike other spaniels.
Training: Stabyhouns respond very poorly to harsh discipline. They need positive, cheerful motivation.
History: During WWII, the breed was kept safe by farmers in Friesland, recognized officially in 1942.
Fun Fact: 'Stabij' is the common nickname for the breed in the Netherlands.
Breed Fact: Most Stabyhouns are black and white, but brown and white exists and is quite rare.
Breed Fact: Orange and white Stabyhouns are nearly extinct.
History: Stabyhouns were historically used to churn butter by walking on a treadmill device.
Temperament: Stabyhouns are known to be excellent with children and other pets.
Anatomy: They are slightly longer than they are tall.
Fun Fact: The Stabyhoun has a very keen sense of smell, originally used to track moles underground.
Breed Fact: In the Netherlands, they are often seen as national treasures.
Fun Fact: Stabyhouns are not usually barkers, but they will alert you if something is wrong.
Activity: Swimming is great low-impact exercise for Stabyhouns once the water is warm enough.
Breed Fact: The Stabyhoun tail usually has a white tip.
kooikerhondje: Breed Fact: The Kooikerhondje is a historic Dutch duck decoy dog (eendenkooi), used to lure ducks into traps.
History: Kooikerhondjes appear in 17th-century Dutch Masters paintings, including works by Jan Steen and Rembrandt.
Breed Fact: There are only around 3,000 Kooikerhondjes worldwide, making them a rare and vulnerable breed.
Temperament: Kooikerhondjes are sensitive dogs who prefer calm, consistent environments and gentle handling.
Appearance: Their distinctive orange-red and white coat features black ear tips known as 'earrings'.
Health: Kooikerhondjes are prone to Von Willebrand disease, a hereditary blood clotting disorder. Ask your breeder about testing.
wetterhoun: Breed Fact: The Wetterhoun originated in Friesland, the Netherlands, where it was bred for otter and small game hunting.
Heritage: The Wetterhoun is one of two official Frisian dog breeds, alongside the Stabyhoun.
Temperament: Wetterhouns are known for their stubborn, independent nature — they need a patient and consistent owner.
Appearance: Their dense, curly coat is naturally waterproof, perfectly suited for the Dutch wetlands.
Breed Fact: With approximately 2,000 individuals worldwide, the Wetterhoun is critically rare.
History: The breed's name means 'water dog' in Frisian — a fitting name for this skilled water retriever.
